repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Forest Resources Development
            (Forestry I) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Forest Resources
            Development (Forestry I) Project for Sri Lanka was
            satisfactory. The project achieved its main objectives, its
            impact on the forestry sector and institutional
            strengthening has been substantial, sustainability is
            likely, and both the Bank and Borrower performed
            satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the appraisal team should have anticipated
            the development of new investment opportunities and provided
            flexibility in site selection subject to agreed investment
            criteria. Second, most of the public criticism of the Master
            Plan could have been avoided if a transparent planning
            process had been maintained. The Government of Sri Lanka
            should have involved the public at various stages of the
            plan's formulation. Lastly, introduction of a
            computerized database and decision making system has proven
            to be a remarkably successful method for introducing
            dynamism and professionalism into a previously dormant
            Forest Department. However, maintenance of high tech
            management systems requires a longer technical assistance
            effort than was actually provided.

docna.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Forest Resources Development
            Project : Credit 1317 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Sri Lanka - Forest Resources
            Development Project : Credit 1317 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Forest Resources Development
            (Forestry I) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the project are:
            (a) strengthening planning capability in the forestry
            sector; (b) reducing constraint of skilled manpower in the
            sector; (c) improving the management of existing forest
            plantations and establishing new plantations on a limited
            scale to meet projected industrial wood shortages; and (d)
            strengthening research and trial programs to improve sector
            productivity. The project would include the following major
            components: (a) a forestry master plan, including a
            five-year investment program; (b) forestry training; (c)
            industrial wood plantations; and (d) technical assistance.
